para.paratext: Georgia has used the term “best evidence” to mean the original of a document. In the past, Georgia's best evidence rule applied only to written documents[1] whose existence and contents were at issue (typically documents like contracts and wills).

New O.C.G.A. §§ 24-10-1001 et seq., which is much broader than Georgia's former Code and case law, extends the “best evidence” concept to any form of recorded facts or data. O.C.G.A. § 24-10-1002 provides: To prove the contents of a writing, recording, or photograph, the original writing, recording, or photograph shall be required. In Hafeez v. State,[2] the trial court permitted photographs taken from a videotape to be introduced into evidence. The Court of Appeals reasoned that, since the videotape was also tendered into evidence, no best evidence concerns existed under O.C.G.A. § 24-10-1002.
O.C.G.A. § 24-10-1001 defines the terms applicable to the best evidence rule:
As used in this chapter, the term:

“Writing” or “recording” means letters, words, or numbers, or their equivalent, set down by handwriting, typewriting, printing, photostating, magnetic impulse, or mechanical or electronic recording or other form of data compilation.
“Photograph” includes still photographs, X-ray films, video recordings, and motion pictures.

“Original” means the writing or recording itself or any counterpart intended to have the same effect by a person executing or issuing it. An original of a photograph includes the negative or any print therefrom. If data are stored in a computer or similar device, any printout or other output readable by sight, shown to reflect the data accurately, is an original.

“Duplicate” means a counterpart produced by the same impression as the original or from the same matrix or by means of photography, including enlargements and miniatures, or by mechanical or electronic rerecording, chemical reproduction, or other equivalent techniques which accurately reproduce the original.
“Public record” shall have the same meaning as set forth in Code Section 24-8-801.
O.C.G.A. § 1001(1) includes recordings of any kind within the definition of material subject to the best evidence rule. The identification requirements of O.C.G.A. § 24-9-901 would also apply.
Hafeez v. State, 339 Ga. App. 467, 793 S.E.2d 632 (2016).
